item.content:encoded:
I‚Äôve always wanted to do an ‚Äòyear in review‚Äô kinda post to help me reflect upon the year passed and see how it has affected me. At least it gives me a moment to appreciate all the good that has happened in the past year, and hopefully learn from the mistakes I‚Äôve made.

Work

At the end of 2017, I joined MedleyMed 1, an e-commerce company as a full-stack product engineer. It has been a great learning curve, given that it is my first real job and that I had to learn Python and Django, the stack the product is based on, from scratch.

I immediately fell in love with Python ‚Äî it is a well designed, easy to understand language that is so flexible that a noob developer such as myself can start building apps in no time, and yet powerful enough to be used to solve complex scientific problems. Django felt quirky in the beginning but as I started using it, I realised how mature and fully featured the framework and its ecosystem is. Apart from these two, I also dipped my toes into PostgreSQL ü§û, wrangled with Git üí™, wept over Vim üò´, made peace with Linux üòá, and mastered VSCode ü§ì.

Of course, writing code is only a part of my job. I also had to sit through countless meetings, discussions and demos. I learned how important it is to plan out your work and strategy before writing even a single line of code. I‚Äôve missed a good number of deadlines thanks to my poor planning. Although some of it can be attributed to my sub-par debugging and backtracking skills.2 It is something I want to fix in 2019.

My coworkers have been super supportive and helpful throughout and the structure of our team is such that often times we solve problems in collaborative, not-quite-pair-programming kinda ways. I also got to mentor a new member of the team for a few weeks. It was super fun, although I feel like I could‚Äôve been more helpful and approachable to my mentee.3

Personal

I took a bunch of bite-sized vacations this year, and it was super fun to break away from work for a few days at a time and return energized. I Collected a ton of happy little memories from all the places ‚Äî A road trip to Bangalore, a weekend getaway to Pondicherry, a weeklong trip to Delhi, and a day trip to Gulbarga. I realised that I‚Äôd been missing out on the fun of travelling and I will make an effort to travel more this year.

Speaking of efforts, I really made an effort to be in touch with my close friends and spend time hanging out with them. I‚Äôm only now beginning to understand the value of deep, meaningful friendships and the effort it takes to foster them. My friends still think I‚Äôm not trying hard enough so this year it is going to be a quite a challenge üòÖ.

Another effort I made(am making) is to form habits. One of my overarching goals is to be fluent in German by next year. So I‚Äôm making it a habit to practice the language for 20 minutes everyday before bed. Similarly, I‚Äôm strictly following the Pomodoro technique at work since the past few weeks. I don‚Äôt know what it is about the Human mind and incentive based stimuli, but it has worked wonders for my productivity.4 Also, in October last year, I started learning touch typing on a whim. In about 3 months, now my typing speed is ~60 WPM. I‚Äôm proud of myself for that and I‚Äôm more amazed by how quickly our muscles can learn, unlearn, and relearn.

It has not been all sunshine and rainbows for me though. I gained weight and I haven‚Äôt exercised in more than a year, except for the occasional cycle rides. That is something I look to improve in 2019.

Although I didn‚Äôt plan on it, I ended up reading a ton of books in the past year. Thanks to my hour long commute, I have almost a couple of hours every day to pass time. I spend most of that time on my Kindle. I‚Äôll probably write another blog post to share what I read.

Other Stuff to look forward to in 2019

  • In the last week of December I finally got around to finishing the React Course I purchased in 2017 (üò≤, yes I know) and I think it finally clicked for me. Just three years later, no biggie üòÖ. I‚Äôve since been obsessively learing everything I can about React. In fact, I brought this blog back to life just so I could learn Gatsby and remake my blog. So I‚Äôm seriously going to use React at work and elsewhere because it is so good!

  • More books! I can‚Äôt read enough books.5

  • Deliberate choices about time spent in activites, in terms of risk, reward and strength

  • Audit relationships regularly, discuss long-term priorities, issues etc.

  • Ship more stuff, even if it is just MVPs. ‚ÄúBetter done than perfect‚Äù.

  • Understand how the world works6

  • Making lots of lists 7

  • Unlearn and Relearn Math (A man can dream‚Ä¶)

item.title: How I Built Sketch
item.description: Over the last week, I built a fun ‚Ñ¢ and cool ‚Ñ¢ web app to draw doodles and simple drawings. I appropriately named it Sketch . You can‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
Over the last week, I built a fun‚Ñ¢ and cool‚Ñ¢ web app to draw doodles and simple drawings. I appropriately named it Sketch.

You can check it out here: https://sketch.arjun.ninja

Why

I got the idea for Sketch while I was checking out the article for HTML5 Canvas on MDN. Now why was I doing that? Because I recently completed Wes Bos‚Äô JavaScript30 course (great course btw, highly recommend!) and used Canvas element in one of the course lessons. I was immediately blown away by its capabilities and potential. So to dig deeper, I scoured the internet for resources and found myself on MDN.

Process

First, I noted down the functionality my app would provide. writing it down helped me focus and build a Minimum Viable Product.

I started by building whatever I had learned during the Canvas course. With little effort, I had a canvas to draw on and a function to listen to mouse events and translate them to ink on the canvas.

Here‚Äôs an initial UI mockup:

I then added a colour palette, a brush width selector, and a multi-colour brush. The multi-colour brush is my favorite.

I then added touch and multi-touch, with the help of MDN‚Äôs excellent guide to adding touch input to canvases. There was only one feature remaining in my list: Saving sketches as images.

For this, I used the canvas API‚Äôs toDataURL() method to convert the canvas to a base64 encoded string of image/png type, which I then set as the href in my download link element.

<a href="#" download="drawing.png" onclick="saveImage()" class="action">
  Download sketch
</a>

The download attribute triggers a save dialogue in the browser when the link is clicked. Unfortunately, this hack was of no use in mobile browsers because apparently mobile browsers don‚Äôt automatically decode base64 strings.

I said screw it, ship it. And that‚Äôs how I got to my MVP, two days after I started from scratch. I launched the website on GitHub Pages and got good reviews from my cool friends.

item.content:encoded:
When I saw Koi Mil Gaya for the first time in 2003, it quickly became one of my favourite movies. It had elements such as an underdog to achiever storyline, aliens, friendship, and comedy. The combination of all these, along with Hrithik Roshan‚Äôs brilliant performance won me over. I hadn‚Äôt yet seen E.T. then and this movie was the closest my 8 year old self had come to alien sci-fi adventure.

Over the years, among other things, the distinct theme music of the film stuck with me as did the computer interface used in the movie to communicate with aliens.

So as a tribute, I combined both of those to create Jadoo, a web app that attempts to replicate the interface from the film. Works only in Chrome/Opera now. Try it with sound!

Check out the source here.

item.title: DISKPART saves the day
item.description: Last month, when my laptop‚Äôs hard disk failed hard, all my work came to a grinding halt. In a desperate attempt to restore order to the‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
Last month, when my laptop‚Äôs hard disk failed hard, all my work came to a grinding halt. In a desperate attempt to restore order to the universe, I installed Ubuntu on it. I used two pen drives; one as a bootable drive and the other to actually store the OS and data.

Now this make-shift setup worked for a week or so before the performance degradation due to running an OS out of a pen drive became too much to handle. I ended up assembling a custom PC and joining the #PCMasterRace.

Anyway, when I plugged in the pen drives from before, to my surprise, one of the drives wasn‚Äôt being recognized by Windows while the other drive showed its capacity as 2MB(!). I, being a noob at such things, thought there was nothing I could do about the drives..

..until I came across DISKPART utility after thorough googling.

Here‚Äôs what I did:

# run CMD as administrator
diskpart
list disk
select disk 4 #mine was 4
clean
create partition primary
active
format fs=ntfs quick
assign
exit

item.content:encoded:
Introduction

kMITRA is a student-run monthly magazine by the students of KMIT. The magazine aspires to cover and inform readers about science, culture, art, technology, and issues relevant to the student commmunity, in a coherent manner. http://kmit.in/emagazine

I am the developer and designer of kMITRA, something I really enjoy dedicating my time to. Here‚Äôs a brief overview and history of the website from a technical standpoint.

The Logo:

Back-End

The website runs on the WordPress platform. We chose WordPress as our back-end because we believe in the future of WordPress, as a simple, community driven, scalable, and endlessly extensible publishing platform. More than 71 million people can‚Äôt be wrong. Also because it‚Äôs free, lol.

Content

Most of the content, such as text and images is hosted on KMIT‚Äôs own webservers, organized and indexed by the WordPress CMS(Content Management System). Videos, however, are hosted on our YouTube channel. Newsletters are distributed to subscribers in bulk via a Mailchimp server.

Baby Steps

Plugins

kMITRA was required to be a periodical magazine, with new issues every month. By default, WordPress does not provide management functionality for periodicals. After days of head scratching, we finally found a plugin that provided a basic structure for handling issue-based publications within WordPress. This meant that I did not have to start coding from scratch. A few custom functions later, we were satisfied with its functionality.

Design

We then moved on to design. While deciding the font, we were looking for type that had excellent legibility and was optimized for all screen sizes; so we chose the Open Sans typeface for all the text and Playfair Display typeface for bold, eye-catching Headlines.

Layout

The layout or UI is the first thing a reader notices when looking at a website. We needed something elegant and functional for kMITRA, with generous use of negative space to let the user focus on the actual content. It was fairly easy to achieve the desired look of the website using a base theme and custom CSS.

Migration

Since the old magazine, Vipasana, was located at kmit.in/newsletter for a long time, search engines such as google provided links for Vipasana articles using the old URL. This lead to a number of 404: NOT FOUND error messages. I handled these requests by modifying the .htaccess file of KMIT‚Äôs Apache server to include HTTP 301 redirects.

example:
RedirectMatch 301 /newsletter/(.*) http://kmit.in/emagazine/$1
RedirectMatch 301 /kmitra http://kmit.in/emagazine/

Reception

kMITRA launched on 22nd October last year, with only a Facebook page for publicity. The response was, and continues to be tremendous. It has exceeded all of our expectations. The entire team of kMITRA is overjoyed. The dedication of our readers gives us immense hope for the future of the magazine and a sense of responsibility towards delivering quality and engaging content.

Here are some stats:

Note: These numbers are from Feb-Jun 2015 only. That‚Äôs when we started collecting data.

Lessons Learnt

Developing kMITRA has taught me a great deal about the technologies behind it. I now see how exhilarating solving problems can be. It has helped me communicate better with my team and put forward my ideas and views in a coherent manner.

Additionally, I designed covers for some of the issues.

One of my most memorable assignments was creating a special page for kMITRA‚Äôs coverage of Oscars 2015.

I look forward to continue contributing to the magazine during my final year at KMIT.

Technologies used

Front-End

  • HTML
  • CSS
  • JavaScript

Back-End

  • PHP
  • Apache HTTP Server
  • WordPress CMS/CDN
